dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. DOC’S APARTMENT (GORDITA BEACH) - DUSK (1970) DOC SPORTELLO sits half awake on his couch. He looks up, notices someone standing at his door: SHASTA FAY HEPWORTH (20s).

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Is that you, Shasta?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Think you’re hallucinating...?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No... just the new package, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: ... I need your help, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Come in. (... you know I have an office now and everything? Just like a day job.) She walks in, Doc gets a slow rising BONER in his pants... casually tries to cover it up.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: I looked in the phone book and almost went over there, but then I thought better for everyone if this looked like a secret rendezvous.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Somebody keeping a close eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. I just spent an hour on surface streets trying to make it look good.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about a beer? Doc moves to the fridge, Shasta looks around, they sit down at the kitchen table:

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: So there's this guy...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the straightworld persuasion?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Okay, Doc. He’s married.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And the wife -- she knows about you?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: But she’s seeing somebody, too. Only it’s not just the usual -- I think they’re working on some creepy little scheme.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: To make off with the hubby’s fortune? I think I’ve heard this one once or twice...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: They want me in on it... they think I’m the one who can reach him when he’s vulnerable, or as much as he ever gets.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bare-ass and asleep?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: I knew you’d understand.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Are you still trying to figure out if it’s right or wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Worse than that. How much loyalty I owe him.  BEAT...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not asking me. Beyond the usual boilerplate, people owe anybody they’re fucking steady...?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Dear Abby said the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Emotions aside, let’s look at the money. How much of the rent’s he been picking up?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: All of it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Pretty hefty?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: For Hancock Park.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're giving him I0Us for everything, of course...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: You fucker, if I’d known you were still this bitter I wouldn’t have come --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Me? I’m just trying to be professional. How much are the wifey and boyfriend offering to cut you in for...?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So, this... this isn’t just a couple of X-rated Polaroids, then. Dope planted in the glove compartment, nothin’ like that.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: It isn’t what you’re thinking, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, thinking comes later, what else?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, but it sounds like they want to commit him to some kind of loony bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean legally? Or a snatch of some kind?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Nobody's telling me, Doc, I’m just the bait... CLOSEUP - SHASTA’S FACE Looking at Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. Can’t read her face.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Are you still taking those acting classes?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Thing is: I heard you’re seeing somebody downtown.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean Penny. Seeing? Well. Nice flatland chick out in search of hippie love thrills, basically.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Also some kind of junior D.A.?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You think somebody there could stop this before it happens?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: There’s not too many places I could go with this, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l talk to Penny, see what we can see. So your happy couple. Do they have a names?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: It's Mickey Wolfmann.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mickey Wolfmann who's always in the paper? The real estate big shot?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: You can’t tell anybody about this, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won’t. Deaf and dumb. That’s part of my job. You have any phone numbers you wanna share? She gets a pencil, writes a number down, he watches her...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Try to never use it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How do I reach you?

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: You don’t. I moved out of my old place. Staying where I can anymore...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You could stay here...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. DOC’S - STREET - EVENING He walks her down to her car, ‘59 CADILLAC EL DORADO

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Don’t come any further, somebody might be watching by now.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, call me or something...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: You never did let me down, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I’ll...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: No, I mean really ever.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, sure I did.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: No... you were always true... She backs away, gets in the CADILLAC and drives off into the night. MUSIC STARTS. He watches her go... HOLD WITH DOC. DENIS (rhymes with penis) walks up, says hi, they walk up towards town, away from the beach...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hey, Denis, you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Godzilla sez to Mothra, man, ‘let’s go eat someplace.’

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When Doc came in that night, it wasn’t just the usual hungry-doper thing -- it was something else -- and with Neptune moving at last out of the Scorpio death-trip and rising into the Sagitarrian light of the higher mind -- it was bound to be something love-related and I thought I knew what it was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC and DENIS and a bunch of locals, eating pizza. Sitting here are some SURFERS, a friend named ENSENADA SLIM and a lovely young girl, our narrator: SORTILEGE (20s); she speaks in the flesh...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Was that Shasta’s car I saw down the drive?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: She stuck her head in for a couple minutes...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Are you broken up?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Kind of weird seeing her again. Figured next time I did it’d be on the tube not in person... SORTILEGE looks at DOC with sweetness, then at HIS HAIR:

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Better do something about that.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: I can’t say it enough -- change your hair, change your life.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What do you recommend?

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: That’s up to you. Follow your intuition.  (ETC. -- Pizza talk here.)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DOC’S APARTMENT He sits on his couch. THE MUSIC PLAYS. He’s on the phone, it’s ringing to no answer. His hair is rolled into plantation-style knots. He’s rolling a joint.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There was an ancient superstition at the beach, something like the surfer belief that burning your board will bring awesome waves, and it went like this: Take a Zig- Zag paper and write your dearest wish, and then use it to roll a joint of the best dope you can find and smoke it all up, and your wish would be granted. Doc’s wish was simple... (just that Shasta Fay be safe...) He writes on the rolling papers a small note in pencil: “To Shasta’s Safety. With Love, Doc.” Smokes it and calls his AUNT REET (50s) who lives down the street --

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. AUNT REET’S HOUSE She’s applying ten tons of various makeups, spraying some on, applying with ten gallon brushes and dipping her face into other paints.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Make it quick, Larry, I’ve got a live one tonight and a quarter ton of makeup to put on yet --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay. Mickey Wolfmann, what can you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Powerhouse in L.A. real estate from the desert to the sea -- Technically Jewish but wants to be a Nazi -- what’s he to you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Shasta... she came around... told me about a possible plot to snatch up Wolfmann by his wife and her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is Shasta's role in all this?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Like how passionately does she feel about her flame Mickey? I didn’t ask. ‘I love him’ is probably the answer, what else?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Is she paying you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mmm...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Pause. Silence. Big surprise. Listen, if Shasta can’t pay you, maybe that means Mickey dumped her and she’s blaming the wife and wants revenge.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Possible. But say I just wanted to hang out and rap with this Wolfmann?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t recommend your usual approach, he goes around with a dozen bikers, mostly Aryan Brotherhood alumni -- all court certified bad-asses.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait, I flunked social studies: Jews and Aryan Brotherhood. Isn’t there something about hatred?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Mickey’s eccentric. More and more lately. I would say stoned out of his fuckin’ mind, since he discovered drugs, no offense to you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So where would I find him accidentally?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: I promised my little sister that I'd never put her baby in the way of danger.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I’m cool with the Brotherhood, Aunt Reet, I know their secret handshake and everything.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: It’s your ass -- try the Channel View Estates, his latest insult to the environment.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Channel View Estates. The one Bigfoot Bjornsen does the commercials for?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: That’s the one. Maybe your old cop buddy’s the one who should be taking care of your case.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I did think of going to Bigfoot but just as I reached for the phone, history and all, I thought, ‘naaahhhhh.’

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: Maybe you're better off with the Nazis. Call your mother once in a while so she knows you’re alive... Doc gets up and walks to the TV, switches the channel, finds:

dialogues.speaker: ON TELEVISION 5A
dialogues.text: The commercial for “Channel View Estates” comes on after a bad horror movie: It has LT. BIGFOOT BJORNSEN dressed as a “hippie.” He’s wearing an ankle-length velvet cape in paisley, love beads, shades with peace symbols and an Afro wig. He’s like Cal Worthington, except for live animals, he has a pack of SCREAMING KIDS that do cannonballs in the pool of a MODEL HOME that Bigfoot’s showing off and listing details and financing options, etc... Bigfoot turns to the CAMERA:

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Those 1i’l kids, wow, they're really something, huh!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Doc looks confused. Bigfoot, ON SCREEN seems to be looking STRAIGHT AT DOC... and DOC looks back... HOLD THEIR LOOK AT EACH OTHER.  10.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So what's all this now... Fucking Bigfoot. Well, wouldn't you know. Why does the LAPD need SAG cards?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT REET
dialogues.text: I have major liquid liner issues to deal with here, Larry -- I'm getting off now -- She hangs up. DOC doesn't notice and keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc comes into the office, greets PETUNIA...

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Morning, Doc. What's on your head?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Howdy, Petunia. Still married to what's his name?

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Oh, Doc. You've got somebody waiting for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, imposing black man: TARIQ KHALIL (30s, Black Panther style) is waiting for him:

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Doctor Sportello?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's right...

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Tariq Kahlil. Doc collects himself, note pad, etc...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay -- so how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: There's this white guy I was in the joint with. Aryan Brotherhood. We did some business, now we're both out. And he still owes me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a lot of money. I can't give you details. I swore an oath I wouldn't tell.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about just his name?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Glen Charlock.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You know where he's staying now?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Only who he works for. He's a bodyguard for a builder named Wolfmann. MOMENT. Doc writes: paranoia alert.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my asking, Mr. Kahlil, how did you hear about me?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Sledge Poteet.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wow. Blast from the past.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Said you helped him out of a situation back in '67.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: First time I ever got shot at. You guys know each other from the place?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: That's right -- they were teachin' us both how to cook.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I remember him when he couldn't boil water. So if you don't mind an obvious question: You know where this Glen Charlock works now, why not just go over there, look him up directly?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Because Wolfmann is surrounded day and night with the Aryan Brotherhood Army and outside of Glen, I've never enjoyed the company of Nazis.  12.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So send some white guy in to get his head hammered.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: More or less.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: When you were inside, were you in a gang?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Black Guerrilla Family.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And you say you did business with the who now, the Aryan Brotherhood? Can you explain that to me...

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: We found we shared many of the same opinions about the U.S. government.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Alright, that racial harmony. I can dig it. There something else?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: My old street gang. Artesia Crips. When I got out of Chino I went looking for some of them and found it ain't just them gone, but the whole turf itself.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What do you mean ‘gone’?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Not there. Grind up in little pieces. Seagulls all pickin' at it. Figure I must be trippin', drive around for a while, come back, everything's still gone.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Nobody and nothing. A ghost town except for this big sign, ‘Coming Soon On This Site.’ Guess who the builder is...?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wolfmann again.  13.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Can you show me on the map? They look at map. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So you're, like, what again, Japanese?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: How long you been doin' this?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Looks closer to Gardena than Compton is all I'm sayin'.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: WW Two. Before the war, a lot of South Central was still a Japanese neighborhood. Those people got sent to camps, we come on in to be the new Japs.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And now it's your turn to get moved along.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: More white man's revenge. Freeway up by the airport wasn't enough.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Revenge for...?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Watts.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The riots?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Some of us say, ‘insurrection.’ The Man, he just waits for his moment...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: If I can get ahold of your prison buddy, this Glen Charlock, will he honor his debt to you?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: I can't tell you what it is. I swore an oath...  14.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No need.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: And I can't give you nothin' up front.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Groovy with that.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Sledge was right: You are one crazy white motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: I counted.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Lemme look around -- I'll see what I see. Alright?

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Long, sad history of L.A. land use -- Mexican families bounced out of Chavez Ravine to build Dodger Stadium, American Indians swept out of Bunker Hill for the Music Center and now Tariq's neighborhood bulldozed aside for Channel View Estates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC drives down the street, past a bunch of BLACK PEDESTRIANS walking around, looking for their homes... it’s like driving through lost cattle -- DOC pulls his DODGE DART into this UNDER CONSTRUCTION

dialogues.speaker: SIGNS, VARIOUS SUPPOSED TO BE SMALL SPANISH TYPE HOMES
dialogues.text: BEING BUILT... It's quiet. There's a MAKESHIFT MINI MALL erected for the construction crews. There's a BEER BAR, LIQUOR STORE, SANDWICH PLACE and a MASSAGE PARLOR called CHICK PLANET with a row of Harleys precision parked in a row out front.  15. Doc parks and musters some courage, passes over the Harleys -- bathes himself in a white glow -- and enters the massage parlor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc steps in... it's quiet and very dark. A sexy young Asian girl in a bikini: JADE (20s).

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Jade? Please take note of today's Pussy Eater's Special which is good all day till closing time?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mmmm... how much is it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Errr, not that $14.95 ain't a totally groovy price, but I'm really trying to locate this guy who works for Mr. Wolfmann?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Does he eat pussy?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fella named Glen Charlock?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Glen comes in here. He eats pussy. You got a cigarette for me? He taps her out a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Ohhhh. Lock up style. Not much eating pussy in there, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Glen and I were both in Chino around the same time... have you seen him today?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: If you're a cop, you're entitled to a free preview of our Pussy Eater's Special.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about a licensed P.I.?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bambi?  10 11 16. BAMBI comes out, wearing day-glo bikini. Jade reaches into Bambi's bikini bottom and before you know it -- They disappear below the reception desk. Doc watches... ina flash reflected behind him we see a BALD HEAD, SWASTIKA

dialogues.speaker: LATER 10
dialogues.text: Doc comes to... lump on his head... he steps outside, opens the door, CAMERA FOLLOWS HIM OUT TO REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: LAPD, DETECTIVES AND CORONER ARE ON SITE AT WHAT IS NOW A
dialogues.text: CRIME SCENE. A line of POLICE CARS AIM AT DOC led by DETECTIVE LT. CHRISTIAN F. "BIGFOOT" BJORNSEN, eating a chocolate-covered frozen banana and hollering through a bullhorn... Doc steps out, guns aim at him... A DEAD BODY ON THE GROUND BETWEEN HIM AND THE LAPD...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Congratulations, hippie scum. And welcome to a world of inconvenience... Yes, this time it appears you have finally managed to stumble into something too real and deep to hallucinate your worthless hippie ass of -- without wishing to seem impatient -- anytime you'd like to join us, we'd so like to chat...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot, what happened...! I remember massage parlor -- Asian chick named Jade and Anglo friend Bambi --

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Wishful figments of a brain pickled in cannabis fumes, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, I didn't do it.  17.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 12
dialogues.text: Doc is in cuffs, sitting on the ground. THERE'S A CORPSE COVERED ON A GURNEY that is taken past. It is a bloody mess, body parts are falling out onto the ground -- Doc is getting sick at the sight of it.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I can almost pity your civilian distress. Though if you were more of a man and less of a ball-less hippie draft dodger, who knows, you might have seen enough over in the 'Nam to share even my own sense of professional ennui at the sight of one more stiff.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Was, Sportello. Here on Earth we say, ‘was.’ Meet Glen Charlock. Whom you were asking for by name only hours ago, witnesses will swear to that. Furthermore, on the face of it, you've chosen to ice a personal bodyguard of the rather well-connected Mickey Wolfmann. Name rings bell? Or in your case shakes tambourine? Ah, but here's our ride --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Where's my ride?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Like it's owner, on its way to impoundment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc in custody sitting across from Bigfoot.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: So when you and Glen had your fatal encounter, when would you say that was in the series of events?  18.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I told you the first time I ever saw him, he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: His associates, then. How many of them were you already acquainted with?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not normally guys I'd hang out with, Bigfoot, totally wrong drug profile.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Potheads, you're so exclusive. Would you say you took offense at Glen's preference for barbiturates and amphetamines?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yes. I was planning to report him to the Dope Fiend Standards and Ethics Committee next week...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Now your ex-girlfriend Shasta Fay Hepworth is a known intimate of Glen's employer, Mickey Wolfmann. Do you think Glen and Shasta were -- Bigfoot slides his fingers around, makes a "fucking" sign.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: How does it make you feel? Here you are still carrying the torch and there she is in the company of all those Nazi lowlifes?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Keep doing that, Bigfoot, you're givin' me a hard-on...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Tough little wop monkey as my man Fatso Judson always sez.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Case you forget, Lieutenant, you and me are almost in the same business, except I don't get that free pass to shoot people all the time and so forth. But if I was in your seat, I guess I'd be acting the same way, maybe start in next with remarks about my mother. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or I guess your mother, because you'd be me... Have I got that right? Bigfoot pretends to read notes:

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: While suspect -- that's you -- is having alleged midday nap, so necessary to the hippie lifestyle, some sort of incident occurs in the vicinity of Channel View Estates. Firearms are discharged. When the dust settles, we find one Glen Charlock deceased. More compellingly for LAPD, the man Charlock was supposed to be guarding, Michael Z. Wolfmann, has vanished, giving local law enforcement less than 24 hours before the feds call it a kidnapping and come in to fuck everything up. Perhaps, Sportello, you could help forestall this by providing the names of the other members of your cult?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Cult.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: No one would ever be stupid enough to attempt this alone, which suggests some kind of Mansanoid conspiracy, wouldn't you agree? I've been referred to more than once by the L.A. Times as a Renaissance detective, which means that I am many things-- and one thing I am not is stupid -- and purely out of noblesse oblige I extend this assumotion to cover you as well... Enter DOC'S LAWYER, SAUNCHO SMILAX (30s).

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Lieutenant! You know that you don't have any case here, so if you're going to charge him, you better, otherwise --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sauncho, remember who this is you're talking to, it's Bigfoot Bjornsen, renaissance cop.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Charge him or let him go, you have no case...  20.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot, don't mind him, he watches too many courtroom dramas. BEAT. They all look at each other...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: What's the beef here exactly?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: It doesn't have much to do with your speciality, which I understand is marine law.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: There's plenty of crime on the high seas.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: So far we have murder and kidnapping, we can work in pirates if that would make you more comfortable -- either way it's high profile.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Yes, but given your history with my client -- you know this is harassment, there's no case, this'll never make it to trial.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: We probably could take this all the way to trial -- but with our luck the jury pool will be 99 percent hippie --

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Sure, unless you got the venue changed to maybe, like, Orange County -- not as many hippies down there --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sauncho, who are you working for?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Clients pay for work.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I've decided I'm going to kick Mr. Sportello.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: You're gonna kick him? That's assault!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (I think it's police slang Sauncho. It means cut me loose.)  21.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'll release the suspect at the impound garage...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: «+. promise?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Promise. And I'll even give hima ride myself.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Alright, I'm glad we got this worked out then -- remember, Doc: This was like 15 billable minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving in silence. Bigfoot suddenly makes a sharp U- turn --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: To a nice, secluded spot that has ‘shot while trying to escape’ written all over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigfoot walks Doc deep into the mountainside. Finally sits him down, stands over him...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Are you aware of the dictum that dope will get you through times of no money better than vice versa... You'd be surprised how many in your own hippie freak community have found our Special Employee Disbursements useful.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: .-. what do you mean? You mean like ‘Mod Squad’? Rat on everybody I ever met?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Right now there's fistfuls of greenbacks flowing at anything that even looks like local law enforcement. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Federal funding as far as the eye can see... or we could certainly offer you compensation in a more inhalable form... Acapulco Gold. Panama Red. Michoacan Icepack. Our downtown evidence rooms got filled up long ago, Doc. Numberless kilos of righteous weed just for you. Just for trivial information we already have anyway. And what you don't smoke, improbable as that seems, you could always sell.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Are you married, Bigfoot?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Sorry, you're not my type. What does this look like? Or don't they have them on planet hippie?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You have kids?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I hope this isn't some kind of veiled doper threat.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's just strange that here we both are with this mysterious power to ruin each other's day and we don't even know anything about each other.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Aimless doper's drivel and yet you've just defined the very essence of law enforcement. So how about my offer?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yours is the last wallet I'd want money out of, Bigfoot...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOC'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Doc's been released. He's watching BIGFOOT on TV from the newscast at CHANNEL VIEW ESTATES. DOC half watches, smokes the end of a joint and rolls The PHONE RINGS:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hello?  23.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Nobody said you did... Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If Glen was a target, then I am, too. Better not be in contact, man. This is not some bunch of fools like the LAPD. And if you don't mind a piece of free advice - - forget it all. Dial tone...

dialogues.speaker: JOINT
dialogues.text: It's done. He's smoked it all. He lies on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PHONE RINGS AGAIN: It's Bigfoot.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So we sent some Police Academy hotshot over to the last known address of Shasta Fay Hepworth, just a routine visit and guess what?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fuck, no, not this.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Relax -- don't be so sensitive -- all we know at this point is that she's disappeared now, too, just like her boyfriend Mickey... do you think there could be a connection? Maybe they ran off together?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot, can we at least try and be professional about all this from now on.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am being professional. There's certain things I can't tell you because you aren't on payroll. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If anything occurs to you about where they went -- don't forget to share that with me, will you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's the last address you have? Bigfoot has already hung up. The phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Sportello?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I got your number at the head shop in Gordita Beach. It's about my husband. He used to be a close friend of your friend -- Shasta Fay Hepworth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And you're?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hope Harlingen.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay. And he's...?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DOC'S CAR Al7 Driving to Hope’s house. CLEAN OF SORTILEGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside this nice, little house, DOC sits at the breakfast table with a sweet faced young woman: HOPE HARLINGEN (20s). (NOTE: Still need a ref. to her false teeth/calcium/heroin. )  25.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Inside the surf-sax category Coy passed for a towering figure, because he actually improvised once in a while instead of how second and third choruses get repeated note for note?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're right. I love surf music -- but some of the worst blues work ever recorded will be showing up on karmic rap sheets of surf-sax players.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: It was never his work I was in love with. Coy and I should have met cute but actually we met squalid, down at Oscar's in San Ysidro --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: I had just gone running into a toilet stall without checking first, had my finger already down my throat, to throw up the balloon of dope I'd just scored in Mexico and there Coy sat, gringo digestion, about to take a giant shit. We both let go about the same time, barf and shit all over the place, me with my face in his lap and to complicate things, he had this hard-on... Next thing we knew here came Amethyst, and pretty soon this is what we had her looking like... She hands him SOME OLD POLAROID PICTURES.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Everybody we knew helpfully pointed out how heroin was coming through in my breast milk, but who could afford to buy formula? It's a long way from my job now. I'ma drug counselor -- talking kids into sensible drug use... Doc looks very confused for a moment. (What's that?)

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: You're staring at my teeth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Huh? No? (Sensible drug use) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Heroin sucks the calcium out of your system like a vampire, use it at any length of time and your teeth go all to hell. And that's the good part.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So... this thing that happened to your husband?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Whatever he took that killed him, wasn't California smack, for sure.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who was the dealer?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: El Drano in Venice.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Was Coy a steady customer?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Known him for years -- what does a dealer care? Overdoses are good for business --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sudden herds of junkies showing up at the door thinking it must be some really good shit? Something like that?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: You got it. Mr. Sportello, I don't think Coy is really dead.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Did you I.D. the body?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: No. Whoever called me said somebody from his band did that.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be next of kin.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: And this... this deposit showed up close to his disappearance.  27. She brings out a BANK STATEMENT book and shows it to him, points to a CREDIT. Doc raises his eyebrows at the amount.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Interesting sum.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: He had no insurance policies that I knew about... Why would this big deposit suddenly appear in our account and be anonymous?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Is there a picture of Coy you could spare? She hands him a BOX FULL OF POLAROIDS. Doc looks inside. We see: COY HARLINGEN. Coy with the baby, Coy cooking heroin, Coy tying off, Coy shooting up, Coy and Hope out at the beach, sitting in a pizza joint playing tug-of-war with the last slice, sticking his dick in his saxophone.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These were perilous times, astrologically speaking, for dopers -- especially those of high school age, who'd been born most of them, under a ninety-degree aspect, the unluckiest angle possible, between Neptune, the doper's planet, and Uranus, the planet of rude surprises. Doc had known it to happen that those left behind would refuse to believe that people they loved or even took the same classes with were really dead. They came up with all kinds of alternate stories so it wouldn't have to be true.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay if I take this one?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Doc's on his way out. Just one more thing...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How did your husband know Shasta Fay?  19

dialogues.speaker: HOPE HARLINGEN
dialogues.text: She picked us up hitchhiking... I think Coy and her somehow stayed in touch... but I don't know for sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting outfit. Making call to Sloane Wolfmann scene. For poss. over V.O. Petunia here.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVING TO SLOANE WOLFMANN'S.
dialogues.text: Doc in his disguise...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shasta had mentioned a possible laughing academy angle to Mickey Wolfmann's matrimonial drama and Doc thought it might be interesting to see how society page superstar Mrs. Sloane Wolfmann would react when somebody brought up the topic... If Mickey was currently being held against his will in some private nuthouse, then Doc's immediate chore would be to try and find out which one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC rings the doorbell. He's dressed in a disguise of a DOUBLE-BREASTED SUIT, SHORT HAIR WIG, LOAFERS. The door is opened by a sexy young Chicana: LUZ (20s).

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: Who are you supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, here to see Mrs. Wolfmann.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: She's hanging by the pool with all the police and them... come inside.  29.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: So you're the shrink that called?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... Out back, by the pool, LAPD are set up in A COMMAND POST by the pool cabana. They're also swimming in the pool, making margaritas and playing Ping Pong. SLOANE WOLFMANN (40s, British, ex-showgirl) strolls towards the house wearing a black bikini, black shawl, black high heel sandals. She steps into the main living room to greet Doc... and stops, landing in what appears to be the MOST INSANELY GORGEOUS MOVIE STAR LIGHTING IN THE HISTORY OF THE WORLD.

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: Do you like the lighting?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: Jimmy Wong Howe did it for us years ago. LUZ! The midday refrescos now, if you wouldn't mind? They sit down. Luz comes in and pours drinks, shows her ass to Doc while pouring...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Your husband was planning to endow a new wing for our facility -- he actually tendered us a sum in advance. But somehow it just didn't seem right to keep the money while so little was known of his whereabouts. So, we'd like to refund you the sum, and if, and as we all pray when, Mr. Wolfmann is next heard from, why then, perhaps the process can resume.

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: We did recently endow another facility, in Ojai... Chryskylodon Institute.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Kriskleddone? Errrr... yesss, uhhh...  30.

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: An ancient Indian word that means, ‘serenity.’ Are you somehow a subsidiary...?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Perhaps one of our Sister Sanatoria? Enter RIGGS WARBLING. Big, muscular and blond, spiritual coach, wearing a tiny swim shorts.

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: Mr. Riggs Warbling... my spiritual coach.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How'd you do?

dialogues.speaker: RIGGS
dialogues.text: Pleasureable.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (to Sloane) Maybe you can tell us where to send this refund and what form you'd like it in?

dialogues.speaker: RIGGS
dialogues.text: Small bills! Non-consecutive serial numbers!

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: Riggs. Enough. Always making with the tasteless jokes. Perhaps if one of your company officers simply endorsed Michael's check back to one of his accounts?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: SLOANE
dialogues.text: Let me just find you a deposit form... She gets up and walks over to a desk, revealing a low cut back and exposing her back...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're a spiritual advisor, Mr. Warbling?

dialogues.speaker: RIGGS
dialogues.text: And a contractor.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You work for Mr. Wolfmann? RIGGS looks back to SLOANE WOLFMANN, says to Doc:  21 22 31.

dialogues.speaker: RIGGS
dialogues.text: If you can call it work... ... Riggs starts doing some weightlifting nearby and some practice hump-thrusts. LUZ stands in a corner watching...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: watching this circus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luz walks Doc to the front door. She makes eyes at him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I forgot, I, uh, I have to use the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: As long as you don't steal anything.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Muchas gracias, there, Luz. I won't be a minute. INT. PALATIAL BATHROOM —- THAT MOMENT 22 DOC snoops around, goes into a cavernous WALK-IN CLOSET and notices: A RACK DEDICATED TO SOME STRANGE NECKTIES.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: I'm in there somewhere. Keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Huh huh huhuhuhuhu.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: There I am. Cute, huh? My tits aren't really that big, but it's the thought that counts.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Did you ladies all pose for these?  23 24
A guy over in North Hollywood does custom work.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about that chick... what's her name? The one's been missing?

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: Shasta. Yeah. She's in there someplace. Mickey always used to take me in the shower to fuck. never got a chance to do anything on that groovy bed in there.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: Another time, perhaps. You're not really a shrink are you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No. But I do have a couch.

dialogues.speaker: LUZ
dialogues.text: Piscodelico, ese! She flashes her teeth. He hands her one of the FAKE BUSINESS CARDS with his real number on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIGFOOT/DOC scene TBD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 24 Doc is sitting in a lunch spot downtown populated with an assortment of JUDGES, LAWYERS, all completely DRUNK at lunchtime. In walks DEPUTY D.A. PENNY KIMBALL (30s).

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: This Wolfmann-Charlock case. Apparently, one of your old girlfriends is a principal?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I just heard that she skipped.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Put it another way: How close were you and Shasta Fay Hepworth?  33.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, now, I've been asking myself that very question. It was all over years ago. Months? If you hadn't come along, babe, who knows how bad it might've got?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: True. You were a fucking mess when I met you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And how ‘bout now?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Old times aside, have you had any contact with Miss Hepworth, in, say, the last week or so?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, now, funny you should ask because she called me up a couple days ago before Mickey Wolfmann disappeared with a story about how his wife and her boyfriend were plotting to hustle Mickey into the booby hatch and grab all his money. So I sure hope you guys, or the cops or whoever, are looking into that.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: And with your years of experience as a P.I., would you call that a reliable lead?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I've known worse. Or are you all just gonna just ignore that? Some hippie chick with boyfriend trouble, brains all mushed up with dope, sex, rock and roll --

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I've never seen you this emotional, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: ‘Cause the lights are out, usually. I've never had lunch with you before.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You didn't tell any of this to Lieutenant Bjornsen when he pulled you in at the crime scene? And Bjornsen seems to think you're as good a suspect as any --  34.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: ‘Seems to’?? You've been talking to Bigfoot? About me??

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Doc. Shhh. Please. Besides, maybe you did do it, has that crossed your mind yet? Maybe you just forgot? (Maybe you just conveniently forgot about it the way you do so often forget things and this peculiar reaction of yours is a typically twisted way of confessing the act?)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Did do what?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Kill Glenn Charlock.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Kill him? What? How would I forget something like that?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Grass and who knows what else, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm only a light smoker.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: How many joints a day do you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I... I'11 have to check the log book.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You can't remember?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't keep track.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Or maybe you can't keep track.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't think my smoking has any link to the Wolfmann-Charlock, Shasta case --

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: .+. No? Why did Shasta Fay Hepworth dismantle your relationship?  35.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: She had other fish to fry.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Would you say you're still in love with her?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No. Wait, what is this, I'm not --

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hectic week ahead for me, so unless any of this heats up dramatically, I hope you understand.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be nice...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Walk me back to my office? I have to swing by the Federal Courthouse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC and PENNY enter. She guides the way, into the waiting arms of: TWO FBI AGENTS BORDERLINE and FLATWEED... Penny keeps walking, having set him up...

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: I am Agent Flatweed and this is Agent Borderline.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Did I miss an episode...?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: It's come to our attention that not too long ago you had a visit from a black prison militant calling himself Tariq Khalil. We naturally became curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a tiny office.

dialogues.speaker: BORDERLINE
dialogues.text: We like investigating and spending energy on Black Nationalist hate groups...

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: It's the chronology, really. Khalil visits your place of business. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next day, a known prison acquaintance of his, Glen Charlock, is slain, Michael Wolfmann disappears, and you get arrested and let go on suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So what do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Ordinarily, we're the one's asking the questions.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sure thing, fellas, except aren't we all in the same business?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: There's no need to be insulting.

dialogues.speaker: BORDERLINE
dialogues.text: Why don't you just share with us what Mr. Khalil had to say the other day when he visited you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Because he's a client, so that's privileged is why.

dialogues.speaker: BODERLINE
dialogues.text: If it has a bearing on the Wolfmann case, we might have to disagree.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I wish I could help -- but what I can't figure is if your shop is really so focused on the Black Panthers and all that then what's with your interest in Mickey Wolfmann? LONG PAUSE. No one says anything.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: ... Are you guys figuring Mickey's kidnapping as a Black Panther operation? Did they put the snatch on Mickey to make a political point? A nice shot at some ransom money? Flatweed and Borderline blink a lot and look nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe you've at least thought of putting that out there as a cover story for whatever did happen? Can I be frank for a minute?  27 28 37.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED/BORDERLINE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fly me to the moon... let me swing among those stars... Tell Penny how nice our time has been...

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: As a COINTELPRO informant you could be making up to three hundred dollars a month, Larry. Consider that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc comes walking up to his office and sees: JADE and BAMBI, from the Chick Planet Massage, running away from his office, hopping into a HARLEY EARLE IMPALA and peeling out... He walks over to PETUNIA who hands him a flyer for CHICK PLANET MASSAGE PUSSY EATER'S SPECIAL, shakes her head and looks sad:

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Oh, Doc. It's dark and lonely work, but someone has to do it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can explain this... poc turns it over, written across the back it reads:

dialogues.speaker: JADE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Heard they cut you loose. Need to see you about something. I'm working weeknights at Club Asiatique in San Pedro. Love and Peace, Jade. P.S. BEWARE THE

dialogues.speaker: GOLDEN FANG
dialogues.text: Doc notices, out the window, across the parking lot: BIGFOOT'S EL CAMINO parked in the distance, engine fired up and watching Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC sits with a cocktail. JADE, wearing a cocktail uniform, approaches DOC:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: There you are.  38.

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: See me outside, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the club, on the docks, she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I can't stay here long. This is Golden Fang territory. And a girl don't necessarily want to get into difficulties with those folks.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What is it? A band?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: You wish. I just wanted to say how sorry I was. I felt shitty about what I did...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Which was what again?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I'm not a snitch. The cops told us they'd drop charges if we just put you at the scene, which they already knew you were -- so where was the harm? I'm like, so sorry, Larry...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Call me Doc. It's cool, Jade.

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: That copper?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: He's a warped sheet of plastic.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And was it Bigfoot who put me on the Buenos Noches Express? Or did he subcontract it?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I missed all that, man. Last thing I remember was eating Bambi's pussy -- and Puck Beaverton's tattoo -- like it was pulsating...  39.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's a Puck Beaverton?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: He's an asshole you don't want to meet. Me and Bambi, we're so freaked with the BadAss Brigade stomping in there we didn't stick around --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about those jailhouse Nazis who were supposed to be covering Mickey's back?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: All over the place one minute, gone the next. Like a raid, when people know it's gonna happen? They all cleared out except for Glenn.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Like someone forgot to tell him something?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Listen -- there's somebody who wants to talk to you. He thinks you can help each other out. He's a new face. I'm not even sure of his name but I know he's in some trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay... JADE motions over her shoulder... OUT OF THE MIST WALKS... COY HARLINGEN. DOC blinks a few times. JADE disappears.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Howdy, Coy. coy I would've come to your office, man. But I thought there might be unfriendly eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Is this safe enough for you. Out here? coy Let's light this and pretend we came out to smoke. They light a joint and pass it back and forth.  40. coy I'm supposed to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: There's also a rumor that you're not. coy That don't come as such great news. Bein' dead is part of my job image. Like what I do.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Are you working for these people here at the club? Coy I don't know. Maybe. It's where I come to pick up my paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Where are you staying? coy House in Topanga Canyon. A band I used to play for, The Boards. But none of them know it's me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How can they not know it's you? coy Even when I was alive, they didn't know it was me, man. ‘The Sax Player.’ The session guy. Plus, over the years, there's been this big turnover of personnel, like, The Boards I played with have most of them gone off by now and formed other bands. Only one or two of the old crew are left, and they're suffering with heavy doper's memory.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Story is you came to grief behind some bad smack. You still into that? coy No. God. No. I'm clean these days. I spent my time rehabilitating up --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's okay. I can't hear too good. And how can I talk about what I don't hear?  41. Coy is delicate now, sizing Doc up, looking around, words get more whispery: coy The thing I wanted to see you about... Just wondering if you could check in on a couple of people. A lady and a little girl. See that they're okay -- and without bringing me into it. It's down in Torrance. (hands him address) Just see if they're still livin' there. What's in the driveway. Law enforcement in the picture, any details you find interesting --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm on it. coy I can't pay you right now.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: When you can. Unless maybe you're one of those folks who believe information is money, in which case, I could ask you something? coy Bearing in mind that either I don't know or it'll be my ass if I tell you, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ever heard of the Golden Fang? Coy Sure. It's a boat. A big schooner, somebody said. Brings stuff in and out of the country but nobody wants to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Because? coY turns and look out over his shoulder into the HARBOR. It's foggy... DOC squints through stoned eyes... Coy turns back to him: coy That was it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How do you know? coy Saw it sail in. Got here the same time I did tonight.  42.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know what I just saw. coy Me neither. Fact, I don't even want to know. Doc blinks and like that... Coy's gone... Doc is left standing alone, very confused, and paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC looking through binoculars, SAUNCHO is here, over his shoulder. They're looking at a THREE-MASTED SCHOONER, GOLDEN FANG.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Meet the schooner Golden Fang, out of Charlotte Amalie.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Virgin Islands.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bermuda Triangle?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Close enough.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sizable vessel.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: She has a tendency to show up in the middle of the night, no running lights, no radio traffic. See, the problem with this vessel is trying to find out anything. People back off, change the subject, get creepy and head for the toilet, never to reappear... the owners are listed as a consortium in the Bahamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and Sauncho at a disgusting restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Her name isn't really the Golden Fang. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her original name was Preserved after her miraculous escape in 1917 from a tremendous nitroglycerin explosion in Halifax Harbor which blew away most everything else in it, shipping and souls. After World War II she was bought by Burke Stodger.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Burke Stodger, Burke Stodger. Burke Stodger, the actor? .45 Caliber Kiss Off -- Burke Stodger? Sauncho motions to the wall -- a few 8x10 headshots of film stars who have visited the Fish Place -- one of them is BURKE STODGER from his younger days in BLACK AND WHITE HEADSHOT...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: ... Burke Stodger got blacklisted for his politics, branded a communist and was forced to take the boat and split the country. Which is where the Bermuda Triangle comes in..... Sauncho hushes up as the waitress arrives...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Ordinarily I'd have the Admiral’s Luau -- but today I'll have the house anchovy loaf to start and the devil-ray filet. Can I get that deep fried in beer batter?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'll have the jellyfish teriyaki croquettes and the eel trovatore.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: And two tequila Zombies. Waitress leaves, Sauncho back to whispers:

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: «+. so Burke's blacklisted, splits town on the boat... but somewhere between San Pedro and Papeete, the ship disappears, till one day, a couple years later, boat and owner suddenly reappear -- Preserved in the opposite ocean, off Cuba, and Burke Stodger on the front page of Daily Variety in an article reporting his return in a big budget major studio project called Commie Confidential. He followed that up with Squeal, Pinko, Squeal and I Was A Red Dope Fiend.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Soooo00000000 Burke's working again?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: And his politics have miraculously changed. It's wrecking my appetite just talking about what's happened to this great ship -- they removed any traces of soul she once had...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're emotionally involved? With a boat?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Not just a boat, Doc. Something much more. I know why I'm so interested, but why are you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Some story I heard the other night. Maybe some kind of smuggling angle?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: As attorney and client, this story you heard -- it didn't happen to include Mickey Wolfmann?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not so far, why?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: According to scuttlebutt, shortly before his disappearance -- everybody's favorite developer was observed going onboard the Golden Fang. What we call a three-hour tour and back again...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Was he accompanied by his lovely companion?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: «+. Who?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: My ex-old Shasta Fay?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Thought you were done with all that sad bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. Everybody make it back? No one pushed overboard? Nothin' like that?  32-36 37 45.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Let's order you a boilermaker to go with the Zombie and you can start the whole sordid thing over again...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Just asking... anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Word swirling around some of my friends at the Department of Justice says that maybe Mickey Wolfmann's not as missing as we think?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Like gone but not gone?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: A rumor that these guys are trying to broker a Vegas deal with Wolfmann...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Doesn't compute. Say again. Vegas. Wolfmann.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: It's FBI stuff. That's what they do in Vegas... apparently Wolfmann owned some property they wouldn't mind having... The drinks arrive.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmmmmm. +All this good eatin'.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOC'S PLACE
dialogues.text: DOC is on the couch, pretty stoned, watching PRESIDENT NIXON on TV at a Republican rally for a group known as VIGILANT CALIFORNIA. Nixon stands in front of a huge banner promoting them. A LONG-HAIRED GUY IN THE CROWD AT THE RALLY STARTS HECKLING NIXON... SCREAMING AND YELLING.

dialogues.speaker: WILD-EYED GUY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV)

dialogues.speaker: YOU
dialogues.text: FUCKIN’ FAMILY! FUCK THE DOG!  38 46. PENNY comes out of the bedroom, naked and smoking a joint, sees the TV and says...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hey... it's Chucky!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Better get him to a hippie drug clinic! SECRET SERVICE come over and get him. DOC realizes that this WILD-EYED GUY is actually: COY HARLINGEN.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's no hippie! That's Chucky!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who is it? A friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Everybody knows him. When he's not hanging out at the Hall of Justice, he's at the Glass House.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: A snitch?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Informant, please.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And why's he yelling at Nixon like that again?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Now he's been on TV. Instant and wide credibility. The police can infiltrate him into any group they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC, disguised as a REPORTER (ponytail, fedora hat, tape recorder) and DENIS as a PHOTOGRAPHER pull up to the house in Topanga Canyon where The Boards are staying. As they enter the huge mansion, a couple sexy young house GROUPIES come forward with leis and beads and put them around Doc and Denis...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Doc walks through the party...  39 40 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMEDLEY (Spotted Dick band member) and his KEYBOARD. Doc interviews him, like he's a reporter...

dialogues.speaker: SMEDLEY
dialogues.text: This is Fiona...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What do you and Fiona talk about?

dialogues.speaker: SMEDLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, what you'd expect. Association football, the war in Southeast Asia, where one can score, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And how's Fiona enjoying it here in Southern California?

dialogues.speaker: SMEDLEY
dialogues.text: Loves everything but the paranoia, man.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Paranoia, really?

dialogues.speaker: SMEDLEY
dialogues.text: This house... SMEDLEY grows quiet as he notices road manager-types who may or may not be working undercover come near --

dialogues.speaker: DOC 40
dialogues.text: Doc lurks around a hallway and runs into: JADE.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What, you again?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I drove up with Bambi -- she heard Spotted Dick were staying here --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: She's keen on the Dick, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Tuneful and poetic. English, I guess. I had to come along to try and keep her out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: If anybody asks, I'm a rock and roll reporter, okay?  41 42 48.

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I'll tell them about your Pat Boone cover article.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Have you seen the guy I was talking to at Club Asiatique the other night?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's here. Try the rehearsal rooms upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: REHEARSAL STUDIO 41
dialogues.text: DOC makes his way to a SMALL REHEARSAL STUDIO UPSTAIRS. He steps inside and sees: COY, doing some recording with his SAXOPHONE... “Donna Lee."

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Howdy! It's me again! Remember that chore you wanted me to do? COY signals his thumb to a cloister of RECORDING EQUIPMENT. coy What was the, uh, make and model you looked at again?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. You were asking about a older- type VW, flowers and bluebirds and hearts on it? coy No new replacement parts?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: None I could see. coy Street legal? No hassles with registration?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Seemed that way. coy Well, thanks for looking into that, you know, I just wondered the way people do. I'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM AREA 42
dialogues.text: DOC looks in another room, sees a big TEEPEE. He steps inside and suddenly, Coy is with him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coy So you got to see Hope?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: For a minute. She's okay. And it looks like she's been staying clean, too. coy How'd she do it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know. She's back teaching is all she said. Public health, drug awareness, something like that. coy Where?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know. coy -- You're not gonna tell me where?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not even if I knew. coy What -- you really think that I would ever start giving either of them shit?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't do matrimonials. I have a terrible history of putting in, and it's never ended well. coy Don't matter. No way I can ever go back to them.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You can't go back, because if you did...? coy It would be my ass and my family's, too. This is like a gang. Once you're in, you're in for life.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to give away any secrets... But I think I just saw you on the tube at a rally for Nixon?  50. coy And your question is, is am I really one of them screamin' right- wing nutcases?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Somethin' like that. coy I just wanted to get clean... and I thought it was something to do for my country. Stupid as it sounds. They saw something in me I didn't see. These people were the only ones who were offering me that. It looked like an easy call... But what they really want is to control the membership by making us feel we're never patriotic enough. My country right or wrong, with Vietnam going on? That's just fuckin' crazy. Suppose your mom was using smack.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: My, uh... coy You wouldn't at least say something?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wait, so the U.S. is somebody's mom, you're sayin'?... and she's strung out on... what, exactly? coy On sending kids off to die in jungles for no reason. Something wrong and suicidal that she can't stop.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. Uhhhhhh... and Vigilant California, or whoever you're workin' for, won't buy that? coy I never got a chance to bring it up. Look at me around here. I'm lower than a groupie, fetching weed, opening beers, making sure there's only aqua jelly beans in the giant punch bowl in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I do get the feeling you'd rather be someplace else --  51. coy Back where I was would be nice, but it's too late --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Short of actual marriage counseling, if I did just run a fast check and happened to find some angle you maybe haven't thought of with this -- coy Nothing personal, man. But there's too much you haven't thought of. You want to run your check, I can't stop you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can dig you're tryin' to chase me off this, but look, whatever it is you're caught inside, I'm still out here, on the outside of it. I can move in ways you may not be able to... coy The baby? How'd she look?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: A sweetie pie. coy Any sign of them little kid blues?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I couldn't say... coy «+. I've really blown this solo, man.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The original call from these people, where did it come from? coy It's like bein' stuck with a borrowed horn.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Just give me a glimpse here: Who set you up with these people? coy When I first started snitching, I realized how often people ask questions they already know the answers to -- but they just want to hear it from another voice, like outside their head --  43 44 52.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Help me out... coy You'd better find Shasta Fay. Doc blinks and Coy disappears again --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Now... what the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: IN ANOTHER PART OF THE HOUSE 43
dialogues.text: DENIS has made his way into the kitchen... Denis sees Coy drift into the dining room to get something to eat... so he lifts his camera and snaps. Which sets off a bunch of people moving towards them: Doc runs into Jade:

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Doc, can I get a ride, this place is freakin' me out -- They head out of the house --

dialogues.speaker: A SINISTER-LOOKING WOODIE WITH BLACKED OUT WINDOWS IS
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING THEM... DOC drives faster and faster through the treacherous canyon road...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As if things weren't peculiar enough, Doc was managing to put himself on a full-scale paranoid trip about Shasta... JADE and DENIS are in the backseat and start to strike up a conversation as Denis is rolling a joint...

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: And what's, like, your name?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Ashley... do you eat pussy, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: driving, paranoid, bad driver, lights in rearview mirror.  53.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. and how she must have been using, all the time she and Doc were together, maybe since before they'd met, a devoted junkie taking every chance she could to slip out into the fine breezy nights and go someplace they'd've been looking after her outfit for her so she wouldn't have to hide it at home from Doc... just to be back for a while among the junkie fellowship, to have a break from this hopeless stooge she was already planning to split on and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: JADE 45
dialogues.text: gets out of the car --

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the lift, boys.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hey, Ashley?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I thought you said your name was Jade?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: That's just my nom du Chick Planet Massage.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Alrighty, then -- while we're just talking here, is there anything else you wanna tell me about this Golden Fang?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: They're an Indochinese heroin cartel. A vertical package. They grow it, bring it in, step on it, run stateside networks of local street dealers and take a separate percentage off of each operation.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So... you're dealing smack?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: No, but they use Chick Planet as a front to launder money. Should I have told you this earlier?  54.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: See you around. (ALTERNATE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. Just be advised boys, you'll want to watch your step, ‘cause what I am is, is like a small- diameter pearl of the Orient rolling around on the floor of late capitalism -- lowlifes of all income levels may step on me now and then but if they do -- it'll be them who slip and fall and ona good day break their ass, while the ol' pearl herself just goes a- rollin'. Thanks for the lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc walks up and in the building. Like being on another planet.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All this strange alternate cop history and cop politics -- cop dynasties, cop heroes and evildoers, saintly cops and psycho cops, cops too stupid to live and cops too smart for their own good -- insulated by secret loyalties and codes of silence from the world they'd all been given to control...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC comes into HOMICIDE ROOM. BIGFOOT is here, eating a frozen banana.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I hope this will not be another of those unabridged paranoid hippie monologues I seem obliged to sit through.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What if someone died but was resurrected?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Not at first glance a matter for Homicide.  48 49 55.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So - who around here handles resurrections?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Bunco squad, usually.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Does that mean LAPD officially believes that every return from the dead is some kind of con?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Not always. Could be a mistaken or false I.D. type of problem.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But not --

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: You're dead, you're dead. Are we talking philosophy?

dialogues.speaker: LATER 48
dialogues.text: Doc and Bigfoot sitting together, Doc catching him up to speed on Coy's case. DOC gives him a PHOTO OF COY: It's like The Last Supper, Coy as Jesus grabbing food from table.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Just remind me why I give a shit again?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He's worked for the Department as a snitch, he oughta be in your file... BIGFOOT looks at Doc, then the picture: “How much does Doc know?"

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll look into it personally. He motions down a back corridor...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Just want to look in the freezer a minute... come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigfoot leads Doc down a hall and into a room with a CORPSE-SIZE PROFESSIONAL FREEZER.  56. Bigfoot opens it up: INSIDE ARE SEVERAL HUNDRED FROZEN CHOCOLATE COVERED BANANAS.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'm down to a dozen a day now. The therapist says I've made amazing progress. Please, dig in, feel free. I'm told I have to share. He puts the FROZEN BANANAS in the PNEUMATIC TUBE DISPENSER, sending chocolate frozen bananas hurling around Parker Center...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Certainly a lot of these in here. Is the Department picking up the tab? Bigfoot's FACE TURNS AND THE MOLECULES COMPLETELY CHANGE AS HE SEES SOMETHING OVER DOC'S SHOULDER... DOC looks scared stiff... realizes Bigfoot's looking past him, Doc turns -- DOWN THE CORRIDOR -—

dialogues.speaker: SOME KIND WORDS, SHAKING HANDS, LAUGHING WITH A STRANGE
dialogues.text: LITTLE MAN: ADRIAN PRUSSIA. Everyone's all smiles as they UN-CUFF ADRIAN...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Is that Adrian Prussia? I remember him from my skip tracing days... he's the one with the bat... he beat up an old lady with a baseball bat. And why's he... I mean... why's he shaking hands and smiling and kissing babies with the Vice Squad boys again? Which part did I miss? And why's he walking this way??? ADRIAN walks over.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: This you're new partner, Bigfoot?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Here, Adrian... have a banana. Bend over and I'll stick it in for you.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: Fuck you. And fuck your banana. Adrian exits. Bigfoot to Doc...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You guys go back, huh?  50 51 57.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Where do you think Mickey Wolfmann is, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Now that's a good question. (You try Las Vegas yet?)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: And where is that love of your life Shasta Fay Hepworth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Play nice. (Mighty snotty, Bigfoot.)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: And how much could she have really meant to him -- or him to her that he could just let this all get so fucked up?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Best question yet. (Is this multiple choice?)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: There's places you don't want to go, Doc -- better get back to the beach, you smell like a patchouli factory.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT./INT. DOC’S OFFICE - NIGHT 50 Doc walks the long corridor towards his office...

dialogues.speaker: DOC 51
dialogues.text: walks into his office, is deep in thought, locks the door double and triple lock turns and SCREAMS AT THE SIGHT OF A SEXY YOUNG BIKER GIRL: CLANCY CHARLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Remains to be seen...

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Clancy Charlock.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Glen Charlock’s?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about your brother...

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
