dialogues.text: Glen was a shit and bound to have 58. his series canceled sometime. But that don’t keep me from wanting to know who his killer is.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You talk to the police?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: They talked to me. Some smart-ass named Bjornsen. Can’t say it was encouraging. But I guess he’s a fan of yours... Would you mind not staring at my tits like that?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sorry -- I was just reading your T-shirt. So now... you say... Lieutenant Bjornsen referred you to me?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: He sounded a lot more concerned with Mickey Wolfmann's disappearance than Glen's murder, which I guess is no big surprise. Is that a joint? Can I smoke it? DOC pulls out a freshly rolled one.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Here's a new one.../Please... She lights it and smokes half of it down in before passing it back to Doc...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The theory downtown is that your brother tried to prevent whoever it was from putting the snatch on Mickey and got shot for doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Way too sentimental.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Then maybe he saw something he shouldn't have.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: That's how Boris has it figured to. one suck  59.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Another member of Mickey's muscle patrol. They've all dropped out of sight, but last night, Boris called me late. We have some history. Right now, he's scared shitless.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What of?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: He said Mickey was in the deepest shit you could get in all because of this idea that came to him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Which was?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: All the money he ever made -- he was working on a way just to give it back.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Can I still get my name on the list?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: That's what I said!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Why, but why would he want to?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be the first rich guy on a guilt trip lately. He was doing a lot of acid and peyote and maybe it just got to a point... you must've seen that happen.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Once or twice, but it's more like calling in sick for a couple days, breakin' up with your old lady, nothing on that scale.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: He said he felt bad about making people pay for shelter -- that all along he should have realized it should've been for free --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He told him that?  60.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Boris heard him say it... he wanted to build a big place out in the desert where anybody could come and live for free -- called Arrepentimiento.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, and what's that mean again?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Spanish for ‘sorry about that.’ The idea was if there was an open unit -- it was yours for free... anyone from anywhere can have shelter... are you gonna keep holding on to that joint or are you gonna marry it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And what about Mickey's ladies? Any of them object to his big giveaway?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Only one I've heard Boris say anything about is Shasta -- the one's gone missing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Said Shasta was the only one that ever made any sense around there -- she was nervous about Mickey givin' away all his money -- which I guess caused some problems because it made him think that's all she was worried about was her meal ticket -- which I guess was really crazy cause she was in love with him. Deeply in love...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Shasta and I lived for a short while together and I can't say for sure how deep it went. How she really felt about me.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I hope this ain't a bummer for you to be hearin’...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Clancy, I only look like an evil motherfucker... secretly, I'm as sentimental as any ex-old man.  52 61.

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: You are a pretty dangerous hombre, I can see that... but, as one who's been down this particular exit ramp -- you can only cruise the boulevards of regret so far, and then you've got to get back up onto the freeway again.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who else does he think was worried about Mickey's big giveaway? Business partners? The wife?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: That cop friend of yours kept showing up at the house all the time warning Mickey...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot? So he warned Mickey to what?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: I don't know. (Mickey didn't listen to advice... maybe he said don't give away all your money? Stop doing peyote? Stop doing acid? You're the detective.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clancy and Doc step out of the office. She has TWO BIKERS waiting for her...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Clancy. Driving to get postcard... NO SORTILEGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc walks up to his place... a FEW SHADOWS AND MOVEMENTS AROUND click him into a paranoia alert... He sees on the doorsill a POSTCARD... He carefully picks it up, looks it over... it's from some place deep in the Pacific Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish you could see these waves. It's one more of these places a voice from somewhere else tells you you have to be. Remember the day with the Ouija board? I miss those days and I miss you. I wish so many things could be different... Nothing was supposed to happen this way, Doc, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in, places the postcard down and lights a joint, SHASTA'S VOICE CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. you don't remember the Ouija board? Come on, Doc... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «..go stumbling through that city dump of a memory... It had been one of those prolonged times of no dope, nobody had any, everybody was desperate and suffering lapses of judgment.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: DOC and SHASTA with SORTILEGE and a OUIJA BOARD.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hey! You think it knows where we can score?

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Easy as pie, just do it all by yourself. DOC and SHASTA put their hands on it. The PLANCHETTE

dialogues.speaker: TAKES OFF LIKE A ROCKET, SPELLING OUT AN ADDRESS AND A
dialogues.text: PHONE NUMBER. They furiously write this down. DOC picks up the phone and dials. It rings and a FEMALE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Howdy, dopers! We've got whatever you need, and remember -- the sooner you get over here, the more there'll be left for you.’

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who is this? Whom I talking to? Hey! She just hung up.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Did you hear what she was screaming at you: ‘Stay away! I am a police trap!’ You see the problem about Ouija boards -- DOC looks to SHASTA and they RUN OUT THE DOOR, IGNORING SORTILEGE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUNSET, (NEAR VERMONT)
dialogues.text: They arrive at the address in the rain. It's a HUGE, EMPTY, EXCAVATED LOT. Rain water fills it up... it... flows out into the street...  57 58 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC and SHASTA stuff for here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUNSET, (NEAR VERMONT)
dialogues.text: DOC walks over to the area where the vacant lot was... the hole in ground is gone... and in its place, a STRANGELY FUTURISTIC building. SMOOTH, NARROW, CONICAL -- A SIX-STORY-HIGH GOLDEN FANG. DOC walks back down the street.. DENIS is in the car, waiting for him...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Denis, I'm gonna look around for a while, you want to wait in the car or come in and cover my back?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I was gonna go try and finda pizza, if that's okay?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And you remember that this is a stick, not automatic and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Easy as pie, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet. Doc enters. A receptionist: XANDRA (Asian, British, 20s) and a sign that reads: “Golden Fang Enterprises/Corporate HQ.”

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hi, Xandra. This is the address they told me at the Club Asiatique in San Pedro? Just here to pick up a package for the management? XANDRA reaches for a telephone, punches some numbers, murmurs into it. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: XANDRA
dialogues.text: Follow me. She guides him down a hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts him in an empty office.

dialogues.speaker: XANDRA
dialogues.text: Dr. Blatnoyd will see you ina moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: DR. RUDY BLATNOYD (50s) enters, wearing an eggplant velour double-breasted suit; high-energy. Blatnoyd flips open a three-ring binder, looks it over, then looks up at Doc:

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: So... you have some I.D., I imagine? Doc goes into his wallet, pulls out a business card from a Chinese head shop.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: I can't read this... it's in some... Oriental... what is this, Chinese?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well... I figured that you, being Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: What? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The... the Golden Fang...?

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: It's a syndicate. Most of us happen to be dentists. A syndicate of dentists. Set up long ago for tax purposes, all legit... Wait, where did you tell Xandra you were from again?

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Why, you're another one of those hippie dopefiends, aren't you? My goodness! Here for a little perking up, I'll bet -- He brings out a tall CYLINDER of BROWN GLASS.  60 61 66.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Dig it! Just in from Darmstadt, lab quality, maybe I'll even have some with you -- He dumps the PHARMACEUTICAL COCAINE out on the table, arranges some lines, offers some to DOC.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I try not to do dope I can't pay for, ‘s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Wooooo! No worries. It's on the house.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, just to be sociable, I guess... XANDRA enters, seductively:

dialogues.speaker: XANDRA
dialogues.text: Doctor? I think there's a problem with the couch in your office. And bring that bottle... Blatnoyd grabs the cylinder, runs after Xandra, unzipping his pants as he goes... DOC does some snooping... He goes to what looks like a closet door, he opens it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pristine, long and narrow DENTAL OPERATION ROOM. ROWS OF DENTIST CHAIRS, EQUIPMENT ETC. A few chairs are occupied by clients (mostly hippie-types, cleaned up) There are DOCTORS and SEXY DENTAL ASSISTANTS wearing surgical masks. Some of them look up, see DOC, then go back to their patients. Doc takes this all in...

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN RUDY'S OFFICE 61
dialogues.text: Doc comes back in...

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Hi, Dr. Rudy... I'm back...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're not Dr. Rudy...

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: You're not Dr. Rudy... A young girl has entered Blatnoyd's office: JAPONICA FENWAY (20). Doc recognizes her.  67.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's at Japonica, ain't it? Japonica Fenway? Imagine meeting you here... Doc walks slowly towards Japonica...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This was not a moment he'd been either dreading or hoping for, though now and then somebody would remind him of the ancient American Indian belief that if you save somebody's life, you are responsible for them from then on, forever, and he would wonder if any of that applied to his history with Japonica here... (more??)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So... what have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Oh. Escaping mostly? There's this, like, place my parents keep sending me to?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Escaping? Escaping what?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Chryskylodon Institute.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Place up in Ojai...?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: You know it? DR. BLATNOYD comes bursting back into the room, zipping up his pants --

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Japonica? I thought we'd agreed never to --

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: I escaped again, Rudy...

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: (to Doc) What are you still doing here?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LOBBY
dialogues.text: DENIS is walking around aimlessly looking for Doc. He's holding THE STEERING WHEEL from Doc's car and calling his name... Xandra is running behind him, zipping up her skirt...

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Doc? Doc? Where are you Doc?

dialogues.speaker: XANDRA
dialogues.text: No, no, no, where are you going? Come back here...! 63 INT. DR. BLATNOYD’S OFFICE 63 Denis enters into Blatnoyd's office --

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Hey, man... your ride's in a body shop.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What is it this time?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I sort of mashed the front end. I was looking at these chicks out on Little Santa Monica --

dialogues.speaker: XANDRA
dialogues.text: I told you you couldn't come up here! (to Japonica) Oh. How lovely. Smile Maintenance Chick.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Miss Fenway may seem a little psychotic today --

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Groovy.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Denis...

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: It's not 'groovy' to be insane. Japonica here has been institutionalized for it.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: They put those volts in your head?  64 65 69.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Volts and volts and volts.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Bad for la cabeza.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Let's go, Denis, we gotta figure out a way to catch a bus back to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: If you need a ride, I'm heading that way --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Cop-friendly? Everything cool with your ride, Japonica? Brake lights, license plates, so forth?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: A-okay.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Mind if I tag along with you people? Contingencies of the road and so forth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Okay. That's a good idea... and why don't we doa little bit more of that for the road --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARKED. They all get in, DR. BLATNOYD pushes a MARKET BAG under the seat...

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What's in that bag you’re stuffing under Doc's seat?

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Pay no attention to that bag. It will only make everybody paranoid. JAPONICA starts the car and pulls out into traffic --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Japonica humming throughout --  66 70.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ah, Japonica -- your lights? It'd be groovy, Japonica, really to have some lights working seeing's how Beverly Hills cops are known to lurk uphill on these different cross streets? Just waiting for minor violations like lights to pop folks on?

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Everything all right, baby? Um, Japonica, dear? That was a red light?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: I don't think so... I think that was one of it's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, well, yes, we can sure dig that, Japonica, but then again --

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: No, no, there's no ‘it’ watching you! Those are not ‘eyes,’ those are warnings to come to a full stop and wait till the light turns green, don't you remember learning that in school? POLICE LIGHTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been pulled over by the POLICE. Doc tries to calm everyone, etc... TWO ROOKIE COPS walk up to the car looking cautious and careful... GUNS RAISED and SHAKING VISIBLY... nervous as they approach the car.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Are you the Great Beast?

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: No no no, that's a policeman, Japonica, who only wants to make sure you're all right.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You know you were driving without your headlights, miss?

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: But I can see in the dark.  67 71.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Her sister went into labor an hour ago and Miss Fenway promised she'd be there in time to see the baby born, so she might've been a little inattentive back there.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: That case, maybe somebody else ought to be driving. And we'll need everybody's I.D.s, too.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sure thing. What's it about, officer?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Every gathering of three or more civilians is now defined as a potential cult --

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What!? Charlie Manson again?

dialogues.speaker: NEXT COP
dialogues.text: (to Cop) Did you hear that? He called him Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Shush -- Criteria including references to the book of Revelation, males with shoulder- length hair or longer and endangerment through automotive absentmindedness, all of which you folks have been exhibiting.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we're in a Mercedes and it's only painted one color!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Denis -- DOC notices that both COPS are very subtly SHAKING.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: We'll hand this all in, Mr. Sportello, and unless there's wants or warrants we don't know about, you won't hear any more on this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've pulled up out front of a massive Bel Air home wit a GATE AND A MOAT. BLATNOYD gets his BAG, climbs out of the car... goes to the INTERCOM on the gate, says --  72.

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Evening, Henrich. -- and the gate opens... he says --

dialogues.speaker: BLATNOYD
dialogues.text: Won't be a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Aren't you the man you found me and brought me back to my dad that time?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I was only doing my job.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: Did he really want me back?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He seemed like your standard worried parent.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: He's an asshole. She's emotional. DOC gives her a card.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Here, this is my office number. I don't have regular hours, so you may not always find me in.

dialogues.speaker: JAPONICA
dialogues.text: If it's meant to be...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INTERCOM VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dr. Blatnoyd wishes to inform you that he will be remaining as our guest and there is no further need for you to wait...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Where's SHASTA? Reminder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC walks up to his office, past PETUNIA, who tries to delay him. She isn't wearing underwear and she opens her legs...

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Oh, Doc, do you really have to go in right away? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's been ages since we had one of our interesting chats.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Petunia, are you trying to tell me I have visitors waiting?

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not exactly visitors?

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Not exactly waiting? He opens up and looks inside:

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY CHARLOCK AND TARIQ KHALIL 69
dialogues.text: are on Doc's desk, fucking. TARIQ looks up.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Hey, Doctor Sportello, my man. This is all right, isn't it? DOC closes the door, and looks at Petunia:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Petunia, I know you have the soul of a matchmaker and normally I'm groovy with intimacy of all kinds, but not between elements in a case I'm working on. Too much information I end up never seeing --

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: But it's too late, can't you see? They're in love! I'm just the karmic facilitator! I really have a gift for knowing who's supposed to be together and who's not and I'm never wrong. Love is the only thing that will ever save us!!!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who?                        ?!

dialogues.speaker: PETUNIA
dialogues.text: Everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC is making them some coffee. CLANCY is sitting by TARIQ, encouraging his sharing with Doc... PETUNIA here, too.

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Alright... When I came here first time, I should've told you the whole thing. Too late now, but I still could've trusted you more...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: (to Tariq) You need to tell him the whole thing...

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Glenn didn't owe me money...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. What did he owe you?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Guns. For my people at WAMBAM. Small arms... and some bazookas.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can dig why you didn't want to get too specific... WAMBAM being?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Warriors Against The Man Black Armed Militia. Glen said he had friends who could score us guns and we're still waiting for our shipment as the revolution rolls on...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And who were these ‘friends’ of Glen's that were arranging the arms deal?

dialogues.speaker: TARIQ
dialogues.text: Some bunch of honky dentists out on lower Sunset. Worked out of some weird-ass building look like a big tooth.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Well. Maybe I can think of one or two places to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out to a dinner with Clancy and Tarig, who are both in the bathroom. THOMAS JEFFERSON's face is on a NICKEL emblem all over this restaurant. THOMAS JEFFERSON appears, sitting in a booth next to DOC, drinking coffee, says:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (You look familiar -- are you the guy on the nickel?)

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Thomas Jefferson. So. Guns and Opium. The Golden Fang not only traffic in enslavement, they peddle the implements of liberation as well.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah... but as a founding father, don't you get freaked out a little with this revolution talk?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants. It is its natural manure.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, and what about when the patriots and tyrants turn out to be the same people?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: As long as they bleed is the thing. Doc deep in thought...

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: A nickel for your thoughts...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Glen Charlock... If Glen was tight with the Golden Fang, could they be the ones who took him out? Is he just another Rudy Blatnoyd, DDS who touched some acupressure point on the mysterious body of the Golden Fang so uncomfortably he had to be dealt with?  76.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Nobody trusted Glen -- the Aryan Brotherhood had him shitlisted as a traitor to his race, the Vigilant California was more than eager to help -- and the raid on Channel View Estates was a cover for the hit on Glen --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And so Mickey Wolfmann...?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Mickey was a witness -- he walked in on something he shouldn't have the V.C. commandoes hustled him off -- Then the Feds found out, here's an acid-head billionaire ready to give away all his money -- and of course, they had their own ideas on how to spend it. As long time associates of the Golden Fang by way of scag-related activities, they got Mickey programmed into Ojai for a little brain work --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait -- how do you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I'm on the nickel. I'm everywhere. I see everything. Every time a hippie puts his hand out for loose change -- there I am.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: When you put it that way...

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Do you detect a common thread here, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can trust any of these people?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Excellent -- and what, if anything, are you gonna do about it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Me? What can I do? I'm feeling pretty short on optimism right now, sir...  73 74 77.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Put it another way: What will nag you in the middle of the night, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That little Amethyst Coy Harlingen's daughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. little kid blues... Amethyst. Amethyst: Coy Harlingen's little kid -- what's her future gonna look like without her dad? Mistakes aside, Coy certainly doesn't deserve to be without his daughter and his wife -- CLANCY arrives back to the table. DOC looks up:

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Talking to yourself again? You need to find true love, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm happy for you and Tariq. But what happened to that two at a time?

dialogues.speaker: CLANCY
dialogues.text: Doc -- this guy is two at a time -- at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+. Doc is sitting up straight, sleeping. THE PHONE

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Idiots Unlimited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife in the kitchen and his kids run around in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'm in an evil mood myself tonight. Dr. Rudy Blatnoyd, DDS?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...  78.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: «+. has perpetrated his last root canal, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What do you mean dead? Real life dead?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: We found him next to a trampoline in Bel Air with a fatal neck injury. So far we have no witnesses, no motives, no suspects apart from you --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not me. Why me?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Because you were observed in Blatnoyd's company, both of you riding in a vehicle full of drug crazed hippies.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, well, the owner of that car? He's a very well- respected lawyer down in Palos Verdes, his daughter was driving... she offered me a ride? Cops never gave her a ticket? And Dr. Blatnoyd was her friend, not mine?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I think it's time for one of our chats.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVING TO SEE BIGFOOT AT JAPANESE DINER.
dialogues.text: Sortilege watches him quietly -- (ALT: No Sortilege.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIGFOOT has some PANCAKES that he eats with two forks.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'd share these with you, but then you'd be addicted and it'd be something else on my conscience...  79.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «ee. you ever feel bitter you missed bein' up there at Cielo Drive? Stompin' around that famous crime scene?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: You want the truth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Um. No?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Well, here it is anyway: Right now everyone is really scared.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who? You? Me?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Odd, that fear should be running the town again as in days of old, like the Hollywood blacklist you don't remember and the Watts rioting you do —- it spreads, like blood in a swimming pool, till it occupies all the volume of the day. And then maybe some playful soul shows up with a bucketful of piranhas, dumps them in the pool, and right away they can taste the blood. They swim around looking for what's bleeding, but getting more and more crazy, till the craziness reaches a point. Which is when they begin to feed on each other. BIGFOOT takes a BIG BITE.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: This Coy Harlingen matter. On the face of it, just one more O.D., one less junkie, case cleared.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So tell me what you've got... Bigfoot presents some 3x5 INDEX CARDS... displays them like a card trick...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Pick a card... any card... These are Field Interrogation Reports... see if you find anything that looks familiar... Doc picks the card that Bigfoot favors to him.  80.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Puck Beaverton! Excellent choice. One of Mickey Wolfmann's bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Interesting fellow, I hear...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Sheriff's people happen to run into him at the Venice home of the very dealer who sold Coy Harlingen the smack that killed him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So what was Puck doing at Coy's dealer's place?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: The interesting thing about this overdose is that Leonard James Loosemeat, AKA El Drano, was known for this three-percent product... but the report says what killed him was Pure China White No. 4...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Like the kind you'd get from the whole-seller? Like whoever's bringing it in?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I seem to recall that some years ago, just before he went into Folsom, Beaverton used to work for your best friend and loan shark Adrian Prussia...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Your best friend.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: And this dealer El Drano also happened to be one of Prussia's steady customers. Maybe Puck was there on Adrian's behalf? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I think you and Adrian have a history you're not sharing... BIGFOOT screams to the Japanese WAITERS.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE WAITER
dialogues.text: You got it, Lieutenant!  81.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: (to Doc) Pancakes aren't quite as good as my mother’s -- what I really go for here is the respect.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Didn't get enough of that from your mom?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: You probably imagine I have a lot of status up in Robbery-Homicide. Who could blame you for thinking that... The reality, however... No Cielo Drive for Bigfoot. No TV movie rights or book deals for Bigfoot... even the extra work is drying up... God Help Us All. Dentists on trampolines. Bigfoot is shaking his head slowly, Doc doesn't know how to deal with this...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay, Bigfoot... DOC writes something on a napkin...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It was dark, windy roads, couldn't make it back there if I tried in broad daylight -- He slides the napkin to him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's the address where we dropped Dr. Rudy. It was about eleven.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: That's just where we found him. This helps with the chronology. Hair and drug issues notwithstanding, I think you're being very professional about this...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Don't get sentimental on me, man, it fucks up your edge.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I can be even more emotionally irresponsible than that. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are certain polygraph keys on this case that if I told you what they were, then the only ones who'd know would be Homicide, the killer and you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Good thing you're not telling me.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Suppose I tell you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Why should you?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Just so we know where we're ‘at’ as you people say.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How about I put my fingers in my ears and scream if you try and tell me?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: You won't do that.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Really? Why don't I?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Because you're one of the few hippie potheads in this town that appreciate the distinction between childlike and childish. Besides... it's right up your alley -- we're officially calling it a neck injury -- DOC PLUGS HIS EARS AND STARTS TO MAKE NOISES "blah, blah, blah." BIGFOOT SMACKS HIS HANDS AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Dr. Blatnoyd had puncture wounds on his throat, consistent with bites from canines of a midsize wild animal. That's what the coroner found.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, now that's mighty weird, Bigfoot. Because Rudy Blatnoyd was one of the partners in a tax dodge that calls itself the Golden Fang Enterprises. I don't suppose you had the SID test out those neck punctures for gold or nothin' like that?  83.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I shouldn't think there'd be much trace. Gold is all but chemically inactive, as you might have learned in chemistry class if you hadn't been ditching all the time to score dope.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What happened to Locard's Exchange Principle? Every contact leaves traces? It would sure be ironic, man, is all I'm saying, if it turned out Blatnoyd was bit to death by a golden fang. Or even better, like two golden fangs.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I don't see why anything like that would be material?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Because it's the fucking Golden Fang.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: The descendent's tax shelter. So what?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not just a tax shelter, Bigfoot. Maybe something much more, more vast.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: And this wouldn't be just more of your paranoid hippie bullshit, would it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And have the lab look for traces of copper. Not the kind that goes stumbling all over the crime scene contaminating evidence -- more like copper, the metal? See, gold teeth are never pure gold, dentists like to alloy it with copper? If you hadn't ditched forensics class to go steal hubcaps to plant on some innocent hippie, you might have known that. Doc gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Bet you almost feel like a cop now, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TO CHRYSKYLDON. Doc and Sortilege, driving in a canyon- type area...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: ... Where you off to?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Someplace up in Ojai called Chryskylodon.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: Chryskylodon? Animal tooth?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ancient Indian word means ‘serenity.’

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: I minored in the classics at Stanford, that's not Indian, it's ancient Greek.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You went to Stanford?

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: It means ‘Animal tooth made out of gold.’ (pause) Have I told you lately how strong I think your morals are, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Thanks, ‘Lege. TURNS INTO DRIVING SHOTS APPROACHING CHRYSKYLODON...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc goes through a security check. Patted down by security guards who are holding GUNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc drives up -- ESTABLISH SHOT... see building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrival and greeting, handshakes outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc walking through with DR. THREEPLY and staff...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: This is our Administrative Lounge... Our Chenin Blanc comes from the Institute's own vineyard... Hand's steady as a rock today, Kimberly?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBERLY
dialogues.text: So happy you noticed, Dr. Threeply... more soup, Dr. Igor?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IGOR
dialogues.text: Thank you, Kimberly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tour continues... picture of Sloane Wolfmann... sign under construction that partially reads, "Made Possible Through The Selfless Generosity Of A Devoted Friend Of Chryskylodon."

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's in here?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: A brand new wing for housing our Noncompliant Cases Unit... Doc sees a bunch of kids cleaning the place... etc... Photo of Sloane, etc...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Doc was visited by the creepy feeling that somewhere close by, in some weird indeterminate space whose residents weren't sure where they were, inside or out of the frame, might indeed be some version of Mickey, not quite in the same way that the lady with the big check was a version of Sloane, but altered and -- he shivered -- maybe mentally or even physically compromised. If Sloane was endowing looney bins with Mickey's money, why not take some credit? Why be anonymous?  86.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Come, let's continue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking the hallway -- TWO VERSIONS -- with dialogue and without.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Have you been with us here before, Mr. Sportello? I know I've seen your face...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: First time I've been down here... normally I don't get much south of South City.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: And ab-normally?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: I only meant that with any number of qualified facilities in the Bay Area, why bother coming all the way down here to us?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I believe that just as chakras can be identified on the human body, so does the body Earth have these special places, concentrations of spiritual energy, grace, if you will, and that Ojai, for the presence of Mr. J. Krishnamurti alone, certainly qualifies as one of the more blessed of planetary chakras, which regrettably cannot be said for San Francisco or its immediate vicinity... Burke Stodger?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Part of our Burke Stodger marathon. All Burke, all day. 24 hours of Stodger. It's quite popular with our patients... Doc and the tour poke their heads in... BURKE STODGER on the screen... Doc watches all the kids watching Burke Stodger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and tour continue...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Come... see our Advanced Therapy Group... Doc advances, sees a bunch of chanters in white robes... «+. THE SOFT SOUND OF DISTANT CHANTING. A group of six or so in flowing robes/hoods... Doc looks a little closer -- one of them is Coy Harlingen... A BIG ORDERLY is sitting in a nearby chair. He's rolling his TIE up under his chin, holding it there, then lifting his chin and letting the tie fall back down.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TIE unrolls, revealing HAND PAINTED NAKED SHASTA WITH HER ASS STUCK OUT. Straight from Mickey's Tie Collection. The orderly rolls the tie back up to his chin... Doc's POV TILTS UP FROM the tie to see the SWASTIKA ON TOP OF THE ORDERLY'S HEAD... is this Puck Beaverton????

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Does that man have a swastika on his head?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: No, he doesn't. That's an ancient Hindu symbol meaning ‘all is well.’ It brings good fortune, luck and well-being, what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Only that it looks like a swastika to me...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: He isn't a regular employee of the Institute, perhaps you should pay no attention to that man...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ah-huh.  88. A MOMENT OF EYE CONTACT between ORDERLY/PUCK and DOC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc continues on tour...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Next, we'll see the Institute's own Zen garden imported from Kyoto. Each pebble, each grain of white sand was transported and reassembled here exactly in place... A STAFF ASSOCIATE RUNS UP.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Doctor -- there's a problem with the volt generator in the Dungeon... (ALTERNATE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, there's a broken volt generator in the Dungeon... (ALTERNATE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor -- the electroshock machine is acting fussy again...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THREEPLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Sportello... He leaves. Doc goes snooping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids cleaning hallways... Doc walks down... 0.S. voice "pssssssst." He goes into a

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Coy is there... coy Thinking of checking yourself in?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: More like lookin' for a way to get outta here. Couldn't afford it. I thought you were supposed to be clean these days -- what are you doing here? coy Bi-monthly checkup.  89.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Why can't you just leave, Coy? coy It's part of the job, it's part of being dead...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You can't go back to your family, because if you did...? coy It would be my ass. I've told you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Or maybe you’re as addicted to this as you were some other things... coy This is a higher discipline. They saw something in me I didn't know I had.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're a snitch, man. Coy I have a gift for projecting alternate personalities --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: A spy and a weasel -- coy I have an addictive personality.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're a stool pigeon, what about your girls, then? What about

dialogues.speaker: THAT
dialogues.text: coy Why are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm not mad at you... coy What else was I gonna do? The baby was gonna die --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: -- you made a choice, Coy -- coy I made the only one I had, man -- doesn't everybody wish they had a different life?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm not mad at you, Coy, I'm just -- what the fuck? With that, COY is gone again... DOC hears CHANTING AGAIN... Something draws Doc to the window... he sees: PUCK BEAVERTON... leading the group of CHANTERS IN ROBES...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was occurring to Doc now something someone said once about vertical integration... that if the Golden Fang can get its customers strung out, why not turn around and sell them a program to help kick? Get them coming and going, twice as much revenue and no worries about new customers... as long as American life was something to be escaped from, the cartel could always be sure of a bottomless pool of new customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc follows Puck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc follows Puck through the water... leads him to a BUNGALOW surrounded by FBI... Doc sees MICKEY WOLFMANN. Doc gets closer... and talks to Mickey... who's lounging on a patio/deck area --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mickey...

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: «+. (Hello, little hippie... how are you?)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: They're helping me wake up from my bad hippie dream...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What did you dream? Mickey... what did you dream?

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: I dreamed I gave away all my money... (I spent my whole life making people pay for shelter... ...when all along I didn't realize it should've been for free...)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who's brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: My friends...

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: The bigger my setback, the bigger my comeback...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: ... Mickey... where's Shasta? Mickey gets emotional...

dialogues.speaker: FBI
dialogues.text: Step away from the subject...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLATWEED and BORDERLINE questioning DOC:

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: You're making things awkward. This curiosity of the Michael Wolfmann matter is inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mickey? No longer even a active case for me, man, fact, I never even made a ticket on it, ‘cause nobody was payin’ me.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Yet, you're up here.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Looking into something totally else. I can see how busy you fellows are, so rather than keep you, I think I'll just... LIKE,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI AGENT FLATWEED comes in...

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Your somewhat out on the probability curve and sure merits a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How close is that, you're already upside my face here.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: I'd say you're the one who's too close. You recognized that subject, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Elvis, was it?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: You're making things awkward. This curiosity of the Michael Wolfmann matter is inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mickey? No longer even a active case for me, man, fact, I never even made a ticket on it, ‘cause nobody was payin’ me.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Yet, you pursue him all the way here.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm here looking into totally something else.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Then you won't mind my sharing a thought. It's you hippies. You're making everybody crazy. We'd always assumed that Michael's conscience would never be a problem. After all his years of never appearing to have one. Suddenly he decides to change his life and give away millions to an assortment of degenerates -- Negroes, longhairs, drifters. Do you know what he said? We have it on tape. ‘I feel as if I've awakened from a dream of a crime for I can never atone, an act I can never go back and choose not to commit. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't believe I spent my whole life making people pay for shelter, when it ought to've been free. It's just so obvious.’

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You memorized all that?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Another advantage of a marijuana- free life. You might want to try it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can see how busy you fellows are so rather than keep you, I think I'll just... LIKE, FUCKIN’ RUN?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLATWEED and BORDERLINE questioning DOC:

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: You're somewhat out on the probability curve and sure merits a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How close is that, you're already upside my face here.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: I'd say you're the one who's too close. You recognized that subject, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Elvis, was it?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: You're making things awkward. This curiosity of the Michael Wolfmann matter is inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mickey? No longer even a active case for me, man, fact, I never even made a ticket on it, ‘cause nobody was payin’ me.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Yet, you pursue him all the way here.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm here looking into totally something else.

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Then you won't mind my sharing a thought. It's you hippies. You're making everybody crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So you guys have your own ideas about how Mickey should be spending his money?

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Yes we do. There's better places it can go -- just look at Mr. Howard Hughes...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: ... Howard Hughes...

dialogues.speaker: FLATWEED
dialogues.text: Bought the Desert Inn Hotel and Casino, a fine investment in the future of Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: .-. Las Vegas...

dialogues.speaker: BORDERLINE
dialogues.text: -- we'd always assumed Michael's conscience would never be a problem after all his years of never appearing to have one. Suddenly he decides to give away millions to Negroes, longhairs and drifters.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: My bad luck and lousy timing. Man sees the light, tries to change his life, my one big chance to rescue somebody from the clutches of the system, and I'm too late. I can see how busy you fellows are, so rather than keep you, I think I'll just... LIKE, FUCKIN’

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPERS 88
dialogues.text: "MICKEY WOLFMANN RE-EMERGES! Opens New Casino in Las Vegas."  89 95.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So in the never-ending battle between the FBI and the Mafia for control over Las Vegas... score one for the FBI... Mickey Wolfmann's money would be now spent a different way, opening the Kismet Hotel and Casino... no more acid-head philanthropist, no more Arrpentimiento... he was now back with Sloane and the kids and back to his greedy-ass ways...

dialogues.speaker: IMAGES INCLUDE A GROUNDBREAKING CEREMONY WITH MICKEY,
dialogues.text: looking reprogrammed. Sloane smiling. FBI lined up behind him... etc., etc., etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc at home. Watching “ADAM-12” with Bigfoot doing some extra work. DOC LOOKS UP TO HIS DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hi, Shasta. REVEAL: INSIDE THE APARTMENT, in beach wear, T-shirt, flower print bikini bottom.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA

He might as well have been bringing me in on a leash. He kept me in those micro minidresses, never allowed me to wear anything underneath... just offering me to whoever wanted to stare. Or grab. Or sometimes he'd fix me up with his friends. And I'd have to do whatever they wanted...

All this time, Doc assumed he'd been out busting his balls for folks who, if they paid him anything it'd be half a lid or a small favor down the line or maybe only just a quick smile, long as it was real. He began to run through the cash customers he could remember, starting with Crocker Fenway and going on through studio executives, stock market heroes of the go-go years, remittance men from far away who needed new pussy or dope connections, rich old guys with cute young wives and vice versa... It was sure a piss-poor record, not too different, after all, he guessed, from interests Coy had been working for. Forget who -- what was he working for anymore? Poss. actressy line here on beach, post-narr.)  94 104.

dialogues.text: Am not. THERE'S A BLUR AND BLAST OF NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 101
dialogues.text: Doc comes out of the PCP fog and realizes he's been HANDCUFFED to something. A bed? His gun is gone. He's in deep shit. He's able to peer out a window, he's on the second floor of someplace with a warehouse. There's a CAR and a MOTORCYCLE parked here... Puck is here ....

dialogues.speaker: PUCK
dialogues.text: Didn't know you were a weekend warrior... I could have gone cheap and used beer... Special treat for you today, Doc. We just got in a shipment of Pure Number Four, not a white guy's finger laid on it between the Golden Triangle and your own throbbin' vein, and there's worse ways to be removed forever from the major-pain-in-the-ass list. Just let me step out here and get you some. Don't go away now. PUCK leaves... closes the door and locks it on the outside... DOC, still in a PCP fog... STARTS PULLING THE

dialogues.speaker: LIKE AN ANIMAL HE TEARS THE BEDPOST APART.
dialogues.text: He stands up on the chair, unscrews the light bulb. It's pitch black. He waits.  115. Puck opens the door... Doc whips the TOILET SEAT INTO HIS FACE, then instantly smashes his foot down into Puck's knee, bringing him down ....

dialogues.speaker: HANDS.
dialogues.text: Doc takes the syringe from the floor, draws up the dope and plunges it straight into Puck's jugular. He gets his gun off Puck...

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Puck? Puckie? DOC gets his GUN off PUCK'S DEAD BODY... and goes into the hallway... Adrian FIRES A SHOT THAT HITS A GONG BEHIND DOC -- THAT RINGS OUT THROUGH THE REST OF THE SCENE. Doc crouches behind a sofa, takes off his SANDAL and throws it in the general direction of Adrian...

dialogues.speaker: THIS DRAWS A SHOT FROM THE PATIO FROM ADRIAN. MUZZLE
dialogues.text: FLASH. SMOKE... DOC trains his gun up... Waits until he sees a DENSE PATCH OF MOVING SHADOW AND

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That you, Adrian?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm fuckin' lunch meat... oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Did I get you?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: You got me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fatal, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: Feels like it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How can I know for sure?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIAN
dialogues.text: Maybe it'll be on news at 11, asshole.  102 116.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Stay there. Try not to croak, I'll call this in. DOC gets into the KITCHEN AND CALLS AN AMBULANCE... BELOW THE KITCHEN, HE HEARS MOVEMENT IN THE GARAGE. He creeps down for a look, his pistol ready --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE GARAGE 102
dialogues.text: It's BIGFOOT, who's unloading a bunch of HEROIN PACKS from Adrian's Lincoln Continental and into a '65 Impala...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot? Bigfoot, what the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Take care of ‘em okay, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You fuckin' lunatic. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'm in enough shit personally with the captain and I've seen you on the range... Nice work. BIGFOOT puts the PARCEL into his car...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And that there, is that what I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Well... it's only one. There's more. Enough left for evidence.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot, Bigfoot, I saw the movie, man, and as I recall, that character comes to a bad end.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I have obligations. Expenses.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: This is the Golden Fang you're about to rip off here, man. The fully fuckin' weird outfit that kills people --

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: That's according to your own delusional system --

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Bigfoot. You're a fucking lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Get in the car. Bigfoot gets Doc in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're driving. DOC is silent, he looks out the window that's open... wind blowing... Bigfoot's driving fast.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're the LAPD's own Charlie Manson... where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: We had to impound your car again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC is waiting out front of the tow yard... filling out some paperwork... Bigfoot is around back... he takes a KILO out of his trunk and plants it in Doc's trunk... Bigfoot brings Doc's car around, hands him keys...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe I should take a small commission for doing your dirty work.

dialogues.speaker: FUCKING PAYROLL, WOULDN'T IT
dialogues.text: Bigfoot gets in his car and drives off... Doc gets in his car...

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Doper's ESP, Doc... doper's ESP... listen to it...  105 106 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc has put the heroin into an CARDBOARD TV BOX. Denis is here with Jade... they hide it in Denis' apartment.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: A new TV!!!!

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOC'S PLACE
dialogues.text: It's the next morning. DOC is sitting on his couch. He's waiting for the phone to ring, drinking coffee. TV playing something... JOHN GARFIELD, He Ran All The Way. THE PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MALE
dialogues.text: It's sure been a long time...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And your name was...

dialogues.speaker: MALE
dialogues.text: This is Crocker Fenway.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Japonica's dad? Japonica's gone missing again?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have something that belongs to some people I represent and they'd like it back...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So not that it's any of my business, but you're a principal in all this?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's only because of me and our small transaction over Japonica that you're still alive...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ever so grateful, sir... so what do we do? I'd come to your house, but don't you live behind a gate in an already gated community?  107 119.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You people do humor?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well... more like practicality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc is here, trying to keep it together. Crocker Fenway (50s, white, lawyer) slides into a booth with him and looks at him, orders a rum and Coke.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. How's the family?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fenway still looks like the Gross National Product and Japonica is fine, if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, thought I saw old Japonica at my doctor's office just the other day... By the way, did you ever run into a dentist named Rudy Blatnoyd?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Yes, I do seem to recall the name, perished in a trampoline accident, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The LAPD's not sure it was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: And you're wondering if I did it? What possible motive would I have? Just because the man preyed on an emotionally vulnerable child, tore her from the embrace of a loving family, forced her to engage in sexual practices that might appall even a sophisticate like yourself -- does that mean I'd have any reason to see his miserable pedophile career come to an end? What a vindictive person you must imagine me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You know... I did suspect he was fucking his receptionist. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I mean, what dentist doesn't, it's some oath they all have to take in dentist school, and anyhow that's a long way from strange and weird sex. Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: How about when he forced my little girl to listen to original cast albums of Broadway musicals while he had his way with her?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Japonica's legal age now, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: In a father's eye, they're always too young. BEAT. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: To the matter at hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So I suppose you want your drugs back. And I also suppose you think I want some money -- but what if it didn't have to be in the form of money...

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Well, money would be a lot easier.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I've been more concerned about the safety of some people.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: ... How much of a threat are they to my principles?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: There's a saxophone player named Coy Harlingen, who's been working undercover for different antisubversive outfits, including the LAPD. He's come to feel lately that he made the wrong career choice. It lost him his family and his freedom. Like you, he has an only daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay, well, anyway, now he wants out. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I can square it with the heat, but there's this other bunch called Vigilant California and... well, whoever's running them, of course.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: My guess is that they'd prefer he didn't disclose any confidential information.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Last thing he'd ever do.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Your personal guarantee.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'll go after him myself he tries anything.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: That's all you wanted. No money, now, you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How much money would I have to take from you so I don't lose your respect?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: People like you lose all claim to respect the first time they pay anybody rent.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And when the first landlord decided to stiff the first renter for his security deposit, your whole fucking class lost everybody's respect.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER FENWAY
dialogues.text: Ah, so you're looking for what? A refund? Plus how many years interest?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Course. Nothin' to you. Just a couple hundred bucks to roll up and snort coke through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sunday morning. Empty parking lot. DOC has brought DENIS along. JADE is in the backseat... They sit in (some borrowed?) car and wait...  109 122.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: «+. You should be getting something for your trouble...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm getting their word they won't hurt somebody.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JADE
dialogues.text: I thought I was naive.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Good people get bought and sold every day. Might as well trust somebody evil once in a while, it makes no more or less sense. A '53 BUICK ESTATE WAGON carrying a BLOND FAMILY:

dialogues.speaker: SON. GOLDEN FANG OPERATIVES.
dialogues.text: The MOTHER is wearing a TENNIS OUTFIT, smoking a cigarette. The son has buzz cut and already looks like a Marine and stares Doc down. The Daughter looks like she has a future in drug abuse. The FATHER and DOC take the dope and put it in the back of the station wagon... MOTHER hands over something to DOC.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: A credit card. Don't hippies have them?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I must have meant, why's your mom handing me this?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It isn't for you. COY HARLINGEN's name on the card. They drive off. The Daughter gives Doc the finger. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc is waiting in the car out front. There's a BUDDHIST PRIEST walking around the yard with some girl groupies .-. he's performing an exorcism... Coy emerges from the house... looking a little paranoid and confused, walks to Doc, gets in the car...  110 111 123. coy Everything's cool...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Drac's a part of the band? So... The Boards aren't so evil anymore? Coy Maybe just confused now and then... you know a band that isn't? I'm officially off everybody's payroll. Burke Stodger called me personally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drops Coy off at his place. Coy just breathes, emotional... coy You know what the Indians say. You saved my life, now you've --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, some hippie made that up. You saved your life, Coy. Now you get to live it. Coy gets out, walks up to his house and is greeted at the door by HOPE and AMETHYST. Hope and Coy start making out... HOPE waves to DOC...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Anything you can tell me about an inherent vice clause?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: It's what you can't avoid.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Like... original sin?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: Stuff Marine policies don't like to cover. Usually applies to cargo like eggs break -- chocolate melts -- glass shatters, that sorta thing... thinking of -- THE PHONE AT THE BAR RINGS, SAUNCHO RUNS FOR IT... he listens, then hangs up...  112 113 124.

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: They got her -- Sauncho runs out as fast as he can -- Doc on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Department of Justice and Coast Guard boats have taken hold of the Golden Fang... Doc and Sauncho watch from the shore...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: If she could be brought back in, into some kind of safe receivership and the owners don't come and claim her within a year and a day -- then she's officially abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: I don't wanna jinx anything -- everybody starts coming out of the woodwork -- multiple insurers; ex- old ladies -- maybe one of your lowlife millionaire friends will end up stealing her at auction -- but!... say there was a legal marine policy in force --

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: «+. you didn't happen to take out a policy yourself, Saunch...

dialogues.speaker: SAUNCHO
dialogues.text: If there's litigation -- I'll be on it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well... I hope it works out for you, man. That boat and you really do belong together... Sauncho starts singing "We Should Be Together," from Little Miss Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOC'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Doc is on his couch. LONG PAUSE, THEN: BIGFOOT'S FOOT SMASHES HIS DOOR DOWN... The door is shattered in a thousand pieces. Doc looks up scared shitless:  125.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Don't get up...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Bigfoot. Bigfoot, man... smash down my door?!?! Come on, man...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: After a long and busy day of civil rights violations, I found myself in the neighborhood and compelled to drop in... just to check and see the current state of affairs of my old stomping grounds. Seeing as your effort to keep lines of communications open with me have been limited to say the least...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I've been busy...

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Trying to figure out which side of the Zig-Zag paper is the sticky side? Then... they both talk at the same time...

dialogues.speaker: DOC/BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Listen... I'm sorry about last night. You? Why should you be sorry? The spell is broken.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Weird.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: Extraordinary... Bigfoot looks over Doc's weed supply... BIGFOOT starts to EAT DOC'S WEED BAG AND JOINTS. HE SWALLOWS... BIGFOOT takes another BIG BITE OF DOC'S DRUGS... FINDS SOME PILLS, EATS THEM UP, TOO.

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: This fucking Gordita Beach has been cursed from the jump. I've been trying my whole life to get out of here. Indians lived here long ago, they had a drug cult, smoked toloache which is jimsonweed, gave themselves hallucinations, deluded themselves they were visiting other realities -- why, come to think of it, not unlike the hippie freaks of our present day. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Their graveyards were sacred portals of access to the spirit world, not to be misused. And Gordita Beach is built right on top of one.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah? And these spirits, can you, like, catch them, Bigfoot?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: You plod along in pursuit, maybe only wanting to apologize and they fly away like the wind, and wait their moment... He heads for the door and WALKS INTO THE WALL.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You okay, brother?

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT
dialogues.text: I'm not your brother.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No... but you could sure use a keeper. Bigfoot walks out the door and falls over the balcony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc driving on the freeway. Shasta is curled up in the passenger seat. A fog is rolling in on the Santa Monica Freeway. Headlights drift ahead and behind him...

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Remember that day, the Ouija board set us off into that big storm?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: One of a couple things I never forgot -- don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: This feels the same way, tonight. Just us. Together. Almost like being underwater. The world, everything gone someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Figured it was Sortilege just settin' us up.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: No, she...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Her Ouija board...  127.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: She knows things, Doc... maybe about us that we don't know...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: This don't mean we're back together.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: Course not. She drifts -- off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SORTILEGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Doc fell into a car convoy, moving slowly, single lane through the fog. He figured if he missed the Gordita Beach exit, he'd take the first one whose sign he could read and work his way back on surface streets. He knew that at Rosecrans, the freeway began to dogleg east, and at some point, Hawthorne Boulevard or Artesia, he'd lose the fog, unless it was spreading tonight, and settled in region wide... Maybe then it would stay this way for days, maybe he'd have to just keep driving, down past Long Beach, down through Orange County, and San Diego and across a border where nobody could tell anymore in the fog who was Mexican, who was Anglo, who was anybody. Then again, he might run out of gas before that happened, and have to leave the caravan, and pull over on the shoulder, and wait. For whatever would happen. For a forgotten joint to materialize in his pocket. For the CHP to come by and choose not to hassle him. For a restless blonde in a Stingray to stop and offer him a ride. For the fog to burn off, and for something else this time, somehow, to be there instead. FADE OUT.
